item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Libel is mainly for publishing and broadcasts, and slander is spoken word. I was just trying to keep it simplified. And I have no idea on whether he would do that or not, but Obama really doesn’t have that much control.

Read full topic

item.title: Fair and balanced
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

You cant say anything that could possibly put him in harms way. The most that happens on Fox talk shows is criticize his policies. But believe me, the way Obama is he would pull a few strings to easily get a rule changed to try to get people who expose him in any way off the air. So if Glenn, Sean or Rush were saying anything remotely wrong they would be bashed quickly for it.

Read full topic

item.title: Fair and balanced
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:16, topic:366955”][quote author=SomethingToHide link=topic=463151.msg3388172#msg3388172 date=1288663406]
How is Fox news slandering? I don’t like Fox not even by a far stretch but it’s not slander if it’s about a public official. That’s one of the most protected parts of the 1st Amendment.
[/quote]
But you can’t have a talk show about how Bush caused 9/11 or how Obama is the anti Christ, Muslim terrorist, or Communist. But you can have a show that just says Obama is dumb, but itd be a waste of tv time.[/quote]

Yes you can. As long as you’re talking about a public official (elected officials, most non-elected officials, and others) and their official capacity, you can say whatever, no matter how untrue or malicious it is. All of that has to do with that, so yes, they can. Something like, he’s committing adultery and he’s not, then that’s different.

Look up Sullivan vs. New York Times and related cases. It’s been determined before.

Read full topic

item.title: Fair and balanced
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

SomethingToHide:

How is Fox news slandering? I don’t like Fox not even by a far stretch but it’s not slander if it’s about a public official. That’s one of the most protected parts of the 1st Amendment.

But you can’t have a talk show about how Bush caused 9/11 or how Obama is the anti Christ, Muslim terrorist, or Communist. But you can have a show that just says Obama is dumb, but itd be a waste of tv time.

[quote=“mwiebelhaus, post:15, topic:366955”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=463151.msg3388154#msg3388154 date=1288662404]
His name is George Soros you fucking morons
[/quote]

One a scale of one to give a fuck. I don’t even register on the scale.[/quote]
One a scale of… ?

Sorry, had to

Moparisthebest:

I’ve said it a thousand times and I guess I’ll say it again. ALL news stations put their own slant on the news, ALL OF THEM!!! Take everything you hear/see/read/watch with a grain of salt, and know that the truth usually lies somewhere between the extremes.

To an extent yes. But CNN has been known to do it more than any others. Fox takes news clips from other news stations that only show a portion of the story to support that networks’ views, and theyll correct everything they say and in some cases show you the video clips that CNN left out of the report.

Read full topic

item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

c|p:

i don’t know who steven colbert is or what this rally for ‘insanity’ is either

A guy on the American tv station comedy central. He makes fun of both sides, but mainly American conservative politicians. He had a high turnout to his rally and the american liberals think that its so awesome and that it puts down glen becks rally because it had a higher turnout. Even though this was hardly a political rally when half the people that showed up can’t vote, I know because a bunch of kids from my old high school went just to fuck around. Its more like a justin bieber showing up at the National Mall and over 200,000 girls showed up to flip ship.
